captions.text: What surprised me the most was
Trey's teaching
methodology in terms of
It's about experimentation.
Hello.  I'm Trey Ratcliff.

Here at Stuck in Customs we get thousands 
of requests from people all around

the world who want to take better photos, 
whether they're landscape photos
travel photos.
Maybe you're in these amazing places, and you
take photos, and they come out just kind of "blah," and you want them to be more magical and more interesting.
Well, this is the tutorial for you.

Basically we went all around New Zealand,
and I set up in many different kinds of

situations - everything from sunrise, to
the middle of the day, to sunset.
And we show you how to set up your camera.
We show you how
to compose different kinds of shots,
and then later
we get on the computer, and in post-processing
you'll also see how I spend time massaging the shot
to make sure that I get the right light levels,
that it has the right feel in the end.
And as I go through the steps
you'll get to know these tools very well.
We have many tutorials for various levels, whether you're a beginner or quite advanced.
We do start out very slow, and the first tutorial kind of
goes in slow-motion,
where I show you all the basic tools that you need to process a photo and make it look magical.

And I make sure that I take time on each of the 
sliders
so you understand where to click and what to do.
Then we jump into more intermediate and advanced techniques.
Maybe you're going to go in this direction someday.
I think you'll really surprise yourself with how easy this is, once I show you how these tools work.
It'll basically allow you to take a photo which is kind of "blah" and make it really magical,
so that when you share it online you'll impress your friends and your family, whether you're sharing it on Google+, Facebook, or wherever.
Most importantly I think you'll really impress yourself with how easy this is

and how this adds a really nice layer of art 
and photography into your life.
This is my second workshop of Trey's.
In this experience
I learned an awful lot
in post-processing.  It was a great time,
a great learning experience.
I really wanted to improve on my landscape photography.
That's always been a weakness.  I've learned so much.
It's one thing to see it with your own human eyes and take the picture yourself,
but to then see the magic that Trey creates

and being able to apply that same magic 
to your own photos,
it's just a rare opportunity.
I stumbled across HDR,
found Trey's free tutorial, and it really just grew from there.
I religiously go to his website every day to look at his next photograph and things like that.
So when I saw this opportunity, it was just too good to miss.
Wow, One word, really.
I'm pleased with what I took away, not only on-site and with camera, but also in processing as well.
Trey may be one of the best photographers in the world, but he doesn't make you feel he is.
I took a lot of great notes, too.
It's almost like flash cards that I can go to in those weird situations, should I ever
encounter a fire dancer
on the side of the road.  From sunrise to sunset and from mountains to no clouds to
wildlife,
All of these things are all different, and they're all great, and they're all so
unique.  But it really helps you become a better photographer
I feel that's probably the biggest shock:
getting better the whole week.  Maybe I was looking at the downside and thinking, "Ah, it's never going to happen for me,"
but sure enough, it did.

title: Trey Ratcliff's Landscape and Travel Photography Tutorial Series: New Zealand

Watching +Trey Ratcliff s Video Tutorial "New Zealand". Guess this is a 
great way for ambitious landscape photographers to get to some "next 
levels" (Creative Live speech here, hate it... :-) ). It feels nice, being 
in the field with Trey. New Zealand must be a great place to shoot and 
live.

comments.text:
Maybe that is what photography is for you... but for many photographers, 
its about taking what you see and combining it to create a beautiful 
picture that is pleasing and spectacular to look at. Creative post photo 
processing brings in an arty aspect to photography that you can either take 
or leave... there are no rules, its just what you personally like.

changed for you since then. Victor Lacken (Lensman)

at 2:03 "Sierra online" instead of "share it on line" at 2:07 and my own 
favorite "Pressure cell without using this year's" instead of "impress 
yourself with how easy this is" at 2:17

comments.text:
Available for order now...  here's a sneak preview I just mentioned in the 
hangout... Come sign up now for the special deal :)

http://www.stuckincustoms.com/landscape-and-travel-photography-tutorial-new-zealand/

comments.author: Emdat Hossain

comments.text: Thanks for the reply. I'll go ahead and buy it.
comments.author: Christopher Smith

comments.text:
Hey thanks for buying the other one! You know, in the past few years I've 
REALLY CHANGED a lot of ways that I process things. My workflow, use of 
presets, sliders, etc etc - everything has changed! So, get the new one... 
you'll love it. And, just in case you don't (1% of 1% chance!) then you can 
always get a full-on refund... so... no risk! :)
comments.author: Trey Ratcliff

comments.text:
Trey, I bought your tutorial back in September of 2011. Does this offering 
you have for a special price if purchased prior to April 10 include 
additional materials and techniques that were not in the older series? I 
have recently upgraded from CS5 to the CS6 subscription service, and there 
are some differences in the newer software that I'm still trying to learn. 
Thank you in advance for your reply.
comments.author: Christopher Smith

comments.text:
*20 Free Student Scholarships for the New Zealand event - say "I Want In!" 
(or whatever) below!*

I wanted to do something good for all the students out there on a tight 
budget.  This new thing is quite inexpensive, but it is still too steep for 
struggling students; I understand.  So just let me know below and 20 random 
people will be chosen on Easter Sunday!  You'll get all 4.5 hours of video, 
my RAW files, everything...  Good luck! :)   See more about the online 
class at http://goo.gl/f4jvc 

(I'm only giving away 10 on Facebook because I like G+ better hehe...) ﻿

comments.text:
I've yet to shoot people. I shoot landscapes and urban scenes primarily. I 
do want to shoot people but need the muse/models.
Don't know if you've seen my work but I have a few albums of here on G+. 
Tell me what you think.
And get behind the camera again, +Vita Tres !!!!

comments.text:
I've looked +Vita Tres . I see fellow photographers out when I'm shooting, 
but I've never seen an organized shoot. Plus I'm aching to try out my old 
school Nikon and the new lens for my dslr.

Thanks +Vita Tres ! I'm excited. I know I have talent but to actually learn

comments.text:
Oh wow! I can't describe how thankful I am!
If you know me well enough, you would know that I'm an a supporter of everything photography related. I love everything to learn about photography be it fine art, HDR, tilt-shift, timelapse etc, etc. I can't thank +Trey Ratcliff enough. He has been an inspiration to my HDR work. So I can't wait for this!

experience every single time
